page.title: 11LOCAL HISTORY: THORNHILL
page.content: Built on a thorn ridge- hence its name- a small settlement, consisting of a few thatched cottages known as Thornhill, is recorded to have existed as early as 1369. In 1662, a new place called "Nue" Dalgarno was erected a few 100 yards SE of Thornhill. During 1779 the two small communities joined up and the name "Nue"Dalgarno was dropped in favour of Thornhill. With the building of the Dumfries to Glasgow road in 1715 the village began to stretch northwards. This road was now used by carters to haul coal from Sanquhar, 11 miles to the north. With an upsurge in population the need for schools, churches and public services created further expansion of the village during the 19th century. Private and public sector housing have since contributed to the present state of the village.
